tn.ref: I know that you can do all things, that no purpose of yours can be stopped
tn.text: You may need to repeat the words "I know." AT: "I know that you can do all things. I know that no purpose of yours can be stopped." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: no purpose of yours can be stopped
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "no one can stop any of your plans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Who is this who without knowledge conceals plans?
tn.text: Most modern versions agree that Job is loosely quoting God's own words from [[:en:bible:notes:job:38:01|38:2]]. Translators may therefore decide, as does the UDB, to make it clear that God asked this question of Job and that Job is now remembering it. AT: "You said to me, 'Who is this who has no knowledge, but who dares to hide my plans from people?'" Or, "You said to me, 'You have no knowledge; you should not tell lies about my plans.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
That is, conceals or misrepresents God's plans and advice. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: but now my eye sees you
tn.text: The reader should not understand this to mean that Job literally saw Yahweh. Seeing with the eye is a metonym for understanding. AT: "but now I really understand you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Job's self is a metonym for what he said. AT: "I despise the things I said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"intensely dislike" or "am unhappy with"

tn.ref: I repent in dust and ashes
tn.text: It is not clear that Job actually did sit in or cover himself with dust and ashes. This may be a metaphor for being sorry for his sins. AT: "I am so sorry for my sins that I should sit in dust and ashes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This phrase is used here to mark an important event in the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
Translate this man's name as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:02:11|2:11]]

tn.ref: My wrath is kindled against you
tn.text: Fire is a metaphor for anger, and starting a fire is a metaphor for becoming angry. AT: "I have become very angry with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"7 bulls" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: I may not deal with you after your folly
tn.text: The abstract noun "folly" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "even though you have been very foolish, and deserve to have me punish you severely, I will not do that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: no women were found as beautiful as Job's daughters
tn.text: "Job's daughters were more beautiful than all the other women"

tn.ref: being old and full of days
tn.text: The words "full of days" means basically the same thing as "being old." The two phrases form a common idiom. AT: "a very old man." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
